Project Number: 54349-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
November 2020 
 
 
People’s Republic of China: Enhancing Skills 
Development System to Cultivate New Generation 
Farmers to Promote Rural Revitalization in Gansu 
Province

Policy.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will provide evidence-based policy 
advice for enhancing  the skills development system for young farmers as part of the rural 
revitalization of Gansu Province in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). It will (i) assess the 
relevance and quality of technical and vocational education and training (TVET) and short-term 
skills development programs, and (ii) promote a needs-based and entrepreneurship-driven skills 
development system for the new generation farmers to contribute to reducing poverty and 
inequality in rural areas.  
 
2.  The TA is included in the list of projects agreed between the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) and the PRC Government on 22 January 2020.1 The TA is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 
2030 Operational Plan for (i) Priority 1: Addressing Remaining Poverty and Reducing Inequalities, 
(ii)  Priority  2:  Accelerating  Progress  in  Gender  Equality,  (iii)  Priority  5:  Promoting  Rural 
Development and Food Security, and (iv) Priority 6: Strengthening Governance and Institutional 
Capacity.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The Gansu Provincial Government is committed to the PRC’s rural revitalization strategy 
for 2018–2022 as it aims to reinvigorate rural areas across the country to reduce poverty, promote 
equity, improve rural development, and support green and inclusive growth.3 To achieve these 
objectives, the PRC is institutionalizing the development of a new type of professional farmers4 
through human capital development, policy support, and social security. Over the last 30 years, 
the agricultural labor force has decreased by more than 290 million as they have left farms to 
work in cities and towns.5 This migration has resulted in an aging farming population6 in the PRC. 
 
4.  In general, female farmers are less educated and have less access to training. Therefore, 
small and medium-sized enterprises led by women are more likely to experience skills constraints 
in developing and selling high-quality products. To improve the productivity and efficiency of their 
businesses and/or farms, women need better access to capacity building and digital technologies 
and communication platforms for marketing. 
 
5.  The  National  Plan  on  the  Development  of  New-Type  Professional  Farmers  for  the 
thirteenth five-year plan issued in 2017 outlines the overarching goals, methods, and major 
 
1  The original TA title, Cultivating New Generation Farmers for Consolidating and Improving the Achievements of 
Poverty Alleviation in the Rural Revitalization Strategy of Gansu Province, was adjusted to better reflect the scope. 
The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 28 September 2020. 
2  ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 1: Addressing Remaining Poverty and Reducing Inequalities, 
2019–2024. Manila; ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 2: Accelerating Progress in Gender 
Equality,  2019–2024.  Manila;  ADB.  2019.  Strategy  2030  Operational  Plan  for  Priority  5:  Promoting  Rural 
Development and Food Security, 2019–2024. Manila; and ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 6: 
Strengthening Governance and Institutional Capacity, 2019–2024. Manila.  
3  Government of the PRC, Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, and the State Council. 2018. Five-
Year Plan on Rural Vitalization Strategy, 2018–2020. Beijing.   
4  New generation farmers refer to those who were born after 1980 and are engaged or will be engaged in agricultural 
production and management. These are agricultural professionals and part-time farmers, college students who intend 
to work in agriculture, and rural returning migrant workers. 
5  Government of the PRC, National Statistics Bureau. 2020. Migrant Workers Monitoring Survey Report of 2019. 
Beijing. 
6  Based on official observations of more than 20,000 rural families, the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs 
(formerly Ministry of Agriculture) concluded that the average age of the PRC's frontline agricultural labor force is 
about 53, with those above 60 accounting for more than 25%.

2 
projects for the education of such new professional farmers.7 The objective of this education is to 
prepare the young generation of professional farmers to (i) use modern technology; (ii) accelerate 
the transformation of agricultural scientific and technological achievements; and (iii) play a role 
as a bridge in promoting the integration of production, education, and research. However, the 
farmers’ professional qualification process is hindered by (i) inadequate and poor quality TVET in 
rural areas, as well as the need for entrepreneurship-driven skills development programs to 
address low agricultural productivity; (ii) limited and/or outdated production skills because of weak 
industry–TVET  cooperation  and  poor  management,  and  insufficient  marketing  skills  to  be 
competitive and innovative; (iii) limited access to information resources, e-commerce, and digital 
platforms; and (iv) lack of well-established and coordinated public services platform for farmers 
and returning migrants, including provision of capacity and financial support for entrepreneurship.  
 
6.  Located in northwest PRC, Gansu is the seventh-largest province in the PRC with a 
population of 26.47 million as of 2019. Despite recent economic growth, it is still one of the least-
developed provinces in the country in terms of income and human development. In 2019, Gansu 
Province’s total gross domestic product was CNY871 billion, of which agriculture accounted for 
12.05%. Gansu’s gross domestic product per capita of CNY32,995 in 2019 was the lowest of all 
provinces in the PRC; 50% of Gansu’s 86 counties were designated as national poverty counties.8 
With 51.5% (13.63 million) of its population living in rural areas, it is also the least-urbanized 
province in the PRC.9 Although agriculture remains an important source of rural livelihoods, the 
opportunities for income generation remain limited because of low productivity and the lack of 
high-quality, well-trained professional farmers.  
 
7.  In  2017,  the  Gansu  Provincial  Government  issued  a  five-year  action  plan  on 
entrepreneurship training for returning migrants, new generation farmers, and rural youth.10 In 
2019, the Gansu Provincial Department of Education started implementing a new plan to improve 
the new generation migrant workers’ vocational skills in order to promote the identification of rural 
talents.11 In January 2020, the Gansu Provincial Government proposed to improve the education 
and training system for agricultural talents and develop skills training for the new generation of 
professional farmers.12 Despite comprehensive policies and plans, coordination among different 
players and the relevance and quality of the training remain inadequate. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  following  impacts:  agriculture  incomes  and  productivity 
enhanced and new generation farmers in rural areas of Gansu Province developed.13 The TA will 
 
7  Government of the PRC, Ministry of Agriculture. 2017. The Thirteenth Five-Year Plan for the Cultivation and 
Development of New-Type Professional Farmers in China. Beijing.  
8  The State Council Leading Group of Poverty Alleviation and Development. 2012. List of Key Counties for National 
Poverty Alleviation and Development Work. Beijing. 
9  National Economic and Social Development. 2019. Bulletin of Statistics. Gansu. 
10 General Office of the Gansu Provincial Government. 2017. Implementation Opinions on Implementing and Improving 
Agricultural Support Policies to Promote Continuous Increase of Farmers' Income. Gansu. 
11 Gansu  Provincial  Department  of  Education.  2019.  Gansu  Province  Vocational  Skills  Improvement  Action 
Implementation Plan. Gansu. 
12 General Office of the Gansu Provincial Government. 2020. Implementation Opinions on Promoting the Revitalization 
of Rural Industries. 2020. Gansu. 
13 Gansu Provincial Development and Reform Commission. 2018. Rural Revitalization Strategy Implementation Plan 
in Gansu Province, 2018–2022. Gansu.

3 
have the following outcome: rural TVET and skills development programs for young generation 
farmers,14 including returning rural migrants, enhanced.15 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Farmers’ education and training policies and practices assessed. This 
assessment will be carried out through (i) a desk review of national and provincial policies and 
regulations on TVET for farmers and short-term training programs with gender considerations;16 
and (ii) key informant interviews with representatives of relevant departments of the Gansu 
Provincial  Government,  service  providers,  farmers’  cooperatives,  and  other  civil  society 
organizations to conduct a demand–supply analysis and to assess the relevance, quality, and 
outcomes of delivered skills training programs with gender considerations.17  
 
10.  Output 2: Case study in four selected areas of Gansu Province completed. The TA 
will support implementation of a case study of farmers’ skills training practices with application of 
gender-sensitive18 research approaches in the following areas: (i) poverty-stricken county (Longxi 
County of Dingxi City, Gansu Province) specialized in traditional Chinese medicine industry and 
animal husbandry; (ii) modern agricultural industry area (Lanzhou New District, a new national-
level district under the jurisdiction of Gansu Province) specialized in modern breeding and circular 
breeding industry; (iii) e-commerce cooperation (Longnan City, one of the main producing areas 
in Gansu Province for traditional Chinese medicine); and (iv) ethnic minorities’ concentrated area 
(Linxia Hui Autonomous Prefecture) to understand the training needs of minority people for 
modern agricultural production and current training practices. The TA consultants will conduct 
field survey; focus group discussions; and interviews with local farmers, their cooperatives, and 
rural migrants, including women, to identify skills needs as well as the need for public services 
and business support. The TA consultants will develop four policy notes based on the findings 
and present these during seminars organized in relevant areas. 
 
11.  Output  3:  Evidence-based,  gender-responsive  policy  recommendations  on 
strengthening  training  programs’  relevance  and  quality  for  new  generation  farmers 
developed.  The  TA  will  (i) support  the  development  of  gender-responsive  policy 
recommendations for improving  the relevance and quality of  TVET and short-term training 
programs based on outputs 1 and 2, and (ii) help strengthen interagency coordination through TA 
workshops.19 The TA consultants will (i) present the survey findings and four case studies during 
an interim workshop with provincial policy makers and concerned stakeholders; (ii) present the 
key findings in a TA final report and a final workshop, including draft policy recommendations to 
support the transformation of rural TVET and skills development programs; (iii) prepare and 
submit to ADB, the Gansu Provincial Finance Department, and Lanzhou University a knowledge 
product on new generation farmers’ skills training; (iv) disseminate the knowledge product to 
policy makers and practitioners from Gansu Province and the PRC; and (v) hold an interagency 
 
14 Meaningful youth engagement will be facilitated by ADB’s Youth for Asia initiative to solicit the status and aspirations 
of rural youth. 
15 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
16 Farmers’ skills development and training policies and regulations will be reviewed and assessed through a gender 
lens to ensure that women’s needs are considered. It will identify whether the existing policies and regulations have 
any differential impact on men and women. 
17 The interviews will focus on female farmers’ needs in terms of training type, content, length, time, and location.  
18 A gender-sensitive case study will apply a research approach that will consider gender as an important variable and 
pay attention to similarities and differences of men’s and women’s experiences and opinions. These will be equally 
valued in data collection, analysis, and presentation of findings. 
19 Agriculture, education, human resource and social security, and finance departments.

4 
meeting to discuss the potential application of the policy recommendations and the knowledge 
product. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $350,000, of which $250,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items 
are in Appendix 2. 
 
13.  The Gansu Provincial Government will provide in-kind counterpart support in the form of 
office accommodation, venues for meetings, counterpart staff and allowances, and miscellaneous 
administrative expenses, including printing and dissemination of TA reports and/or materials. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA. The Urban and Social Sectors Division of the East Asia 
Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants and monitor the quality of their work. 
ADB will engage consultants and carry out procurement following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated procurement staff instructions. The 
Gansu Provincial Finance Department will be the executing agency and Lanzhou University will 
be  the  implementing  agency  of  the  TA.  They  will  provide  day-to-day  supervision  of  TA 
implementation and guide and support to the consultants engaged under the TA. 
 
15.  Implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

5 
16.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated procurement staff instructions.20 
To deliver the expected outputs, a total of 18.5 person-months (1.5 person-months, international; 
17.0 person-months, national) of consulting inputs are required. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China for Enhancing Skills Development System to 
Cultivate New Generation Farmers to Promote Rural Revitalization in Gansu  Province, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.  
 
20 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Appendix 1  7 
Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Farmers’ education and training policies and practices assessed 
1.1. Conduct desk review of national and provincial policies and regulations on TVET training for farmers and other 
short-term training programs with gender considerations (Q1 2021) 
1.2. Hold key informant interviews on demand–supply analysis, and relevance and quality of delivered training 
programs with gender considerations (Q2 2021) 
2.  Case study in four selected areas of Gansu Province completed 
2.1. Prepare gender-sensitive case study research methodology and tools (Q3 2021) 
2.2. Conduct case studies of training practices with application of gender-sensitive research approaches in four 
areas of Gansu Province (Longnan City, Longxi County of Dingxi City, Linxia Hui Autonomous Prefecture, and 
Lanzhou New District) (Q4 2021) 
2.3. Prepare four policy notes with gender considerations and discuss with relevant local government bureaus and 
other stakeholders (Q4 2021) 
2.4. Organize seminars on policy recommendations in each of the four areas for relevant bureaus and institutions in 
Gansu Province (Q1 2022) 
3.  Evidence-based, gender-responsive policy recommendations on strengthening training programs’ 
relevance and quality for new generation farmers developed 
3.1. Organize an interim workshop on TA findings and draft policy recommendations (Q1 2022) 
3.2. Hold  a  final  workshop  to  discuss  the  key  findings  and  evidence-based,  gender-responsive  policy 
recommendations (Q2 2022) 
3.3. Organize an interagency meeting with agriculture, education, human resource and social security, and finance 
departments on the potential application of the evidence-based policy recommendations and draft knowledge 
product (Q3 2022) 
3.4. Prepare a final knowledge product on new generation farmers’ skills training (Q4 2022)
